title: Spring forces - stretch in parallel vs series

content.question: Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> show identical blocks of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> hanging from identical springs, each with a spring constant <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. In Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the springs are connected in series, and the two-spring system stretches a distance <math alttext="d sub 1, equals 0.40 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> from its unstretched length. In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the springs are connected in parallel, and the two-spring system stretches a distance <math alttext="d sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> from its unstretched length. What is <math alttext="d sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
